content.description:
P1 - 10a - Start a few metres to the left of the lowest point of the wall up a curved, low angle wall that leads to a right-trending ramp. Climb the ramp to avoid a roof in the dark, black rock. Step up over an overlap to a ledge and follow the ledge left to the base of a shallow corner system. Climb up the corner trending left to a few steep moves (10a) and up to the belay ledge. 
 P2 - 10a - Club from the belay up a short corner, move left into another short corner and pull up onto a ledge. Gain a beautiful crack in the upper wall and finish up this to the top anchor.

To descend, either scramble up, trending right a bit toward the hiker's lookout and then walk off to the left. Or descend with 2 rappels.
all bolts

The Great Wall proper is the dominant feature of the overall Great Wall complex and has the longest climbing routes amongst the South Peak Crags at around 50m (2 pitches). Once above the short band of moss at the base the rock is generally very clean, solid and offers some excellent climbing. The positions high above Hyacinthe Bay are spectacular.
